itemDescription: Bishop of Worcester; Bishop of Huntingdon (born 1955)

wikipedia_page.main: The Right Reverend Dr John Geoffrey Inge ( INJ; born 26 February 1955) is a bishop in the Church of England. He is currently the Bishop of Worcester in the Diocese of Worcester. From 2003 to 2007, he was Bishop of Huntingdon, a suffragan bishop in the Diocese of Ely.

response: * John Inge, former chemistry teacher and Assistant Chaplain and current Bishop of Worcester
File:John Inge.jpeg|John Inge, Bishop of Worcester
* John Inge – BSc (1977), MA (1994) PhD – Honorary Fellow, Bishop of Worcester

Accordingly, at the confirmation ceremony following Justin Welby's election as Archbishop of Canterbury on 4 February 2013, these were, respectively: Richard Chartres, Tim Dakin, Christopher Lowson, Nick Holtam, John Inge and James Langstaff.Order of Service – Confirmation of the Election of Justin Welby as Archbishop of Canterbury, 4 February 2013  (Accessed 31 July 2013)

Besides the diocesan Bishop of Worcester (John Inge) and the Bishop suffragan of Dudley (Martin Gorick; which See was created in 1974), there are four retired bishops resident in (or near) the diocese who are licensed to serve as honorary assistant bishops: Section: Honorary Assistant Bishops

The Lord High Almoner is usually a diocesan bishop or high cleric of the Church of England. The current holder of the office is the Bishop of Worcester, the Right Reverend John Inge. There is also an hereditary Grand Almoner, an office dating from 1685 and vested in the person of the Marquess of Exeter, but this is not an office of the Royal Almonry and he has no role to play. The actual work of the office is undertaken by the Sub-Almoner (currently Paul Wright), who is also the Deputy Clerk of the Closet of the Ecclesiastical Household, Sub-dean of the Chapel Royal, and Domestic Chaplain at Buckingham Palace.
File:Official portrait of The Lord Bishop of Worcester crop 2.jpg|John Inge
The current bishop of Worcester is John Inge.
